description: Rupert Murdoch has never shied away from controversy, but publishing two books about House Speaker Newt Gingrich simultaneously was apparently more than he could handle.

title: Aiming at H.M.O.'s, Upjohn Agrees to $13 Billion Merger
description: The Upjohn Company in the United States and Pharmacia A. B. of Sweden said yesterday that they would join forces in a $13 billion deal aimed in part at selling drugs in huge quantities to H.M.O.'s and other organizations that buy medicines on behalf of tens of thousands of patients.

title: Team USA Falls to Finland in Final
description: Lulea, last season's runner-up in the Swedish Elite League, beat Team USA, 4-2, yesterday in the final of the Tampere Cup in Tampere, Finland. Finland went ahead for good when Lars Modig broke a 2-2 tie at 2 minutes 41 seconds in the third period against the American team, composed entirely of college players.

title: C.I.A. Re-examines Hiring Of Ex-Terrorist as Agent
description: As the Central Intelligence Agency cleans house after the cold war, trimming its roster of foreign agents and writing new rules for hiring them, a retired terrorist who was until recently on the agency's payroll has given it cause for some soul-searching.

title: Speedometers In the Subway: A Bumpy Life
description: For almost 90 years, New York's subway operators could only guess how fast they were going, and so, in fits and starts over two decades, transit officials searched for a speedometer that would do the job. In 1992, they declared the problem solved, and speed gauges began appearing in the trains.

title: Training Regimen for Culling Ranks
description: Even on the best of days, survival as a freshman cadet during "hell week" at The Citadel is not easy.

title: Johnny Adams, Horse Racing Trainer, 79
description: Johnny Adams, the Hall of Fame trainer who as a jockey won horse racing's Preakness Stakes, died on Saturday at his home in Arcadia, Calif., after a lengthy illness. He was 79.

title: Labonte Brothers 1-2 in Goodwrench 400
description: Bobby Labonte made it a clean sweep yesterday, driving his Chevrolet Monte Carlo to victory in the GM Goodwrench 400 for his second straight victory at Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich.

title: Topics of The Times; Good Sports
description: At the winter Olympics last year, the coach of the Swedish four-man bobsled team asked the Australian captain if he could spare five kilos -- about 11 pounds -- of ballast. He could and did. Sweden then beat Australia, and the accommodating Australian, Justin McDonald, won a Pierre de Coubertin Fair Play Trophy. Another trophy went to Francesco Panetta of Italy, who stopped to help a fellow countryman who had fallen on a hurdle in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the 1993 World Cup. The man he helped went on to win. Panetta, had he not stopped, might have taken a medal, but finished seventh.

title: New York, Through the Tour Bus Window
description: New York, Isaak Borshch informed his busload of Russian tourists, is such a fantastical city that no matter what you say about it, the truth is wider, bigger, more varied.

title: Reborn Mirabella Counts on Itself as Role Model
description: In 1989, Grace Mirabella, who had just been ousted as editor in chief of Vogue, started Mirabella, a new kind of fashion magazine that really was not a fashion magazine. Under the direction of Ms. Mirabella and its top editor, Amy Gross, the magazine became known as a smart, stylish magazine for intelligent, involved women.

title: British Government Wants Big Push for Advanced TV
description: The Government of Prime Minister John Major has announced it wants to push the country within two years into adopting the digital technology to carry high-definition television, with its crystal-clear pictures, wide screens and crisp sound.

title: Taking In the Sites; Way Out West With the Best State Web Site
description: Californians befuddled by taxes or threatened by floods can turn to the World Wide Web to help sort out their predicaments. Often, the information is just minutes old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOOMER ESIASON, the New York Jets quarterback, has ventured into new terrain: he has written a children's book, "A Boy Named Boomer," that has been published by Scholastic Inc.

title: For a Black Squadron, an Enemy Not German
description: The year is 1943. A group of young black airmen en route to Alabama from the North are ordered to leave the comfortable rear car of a troop train and move to the dirty and noisy first car beside the locomotive. As the airmen step out, they stare at the men taking their place: German prisoners of war.

title: New York, Through the Tour Bus Window: Japanese; Whiff of Danger In the Big City
description: Koichi Tarabe had made exactly 41 trips outside Japan in his life, including 2 to Chicago. But fear had kept him from New York, though the city had long gripped his imagination.

title: I.B.M.-Microsoft Feud Roils a Trade Show
description: The simmering hostility between I.B.M. and its onetime partner, the Microsoft Corporation, burst into the open last week, after I.B.M. disclosed that Microsoft had put pressure on the organizers of an industry trade show to remove one of I.B.M.'s top software executives from the program.

title: A Private Investigator's Pursuit of a Police Detective Pays Off for Simpson
description: It was a phone call that turned the case on its head, but to a private investigator named Patrick McKenna, it began like hundreds of other calls he had gotten since O. J. Simpson hired him. The voice at the other end was anonymous, cryptic and hurried.

title: Surprising Straw Poll Gives Dole A Glimpse of the Battles Ahead
description: In the first sign that Senator Bob Dole could be tripped up in his march to the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Phil Gramm unexpectedly tied him on Saturday night in a straw poll sponsored by the Iowa Republican Party.

title: Tyson Is Still A Very Big $25 Million Question
description: It was a scene out of "Casablanca."

title: Grants by Foundations Help Technology Books Make It to the Shelves
description: Richard Rhodes was desperate when he approached the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation in 1984 for help in finishing his book "The Making of the Atomic Bomb." He had used up his advance from Simon & Schuster and a grant from the Ford Foundation, mortgaged his house and borrowed from his mother-in-law, but he was still not finished.

title: Carrying On an Asphalt Legacy
description: In 1950, a Harlem teacher started a basketball tournament to help impoverished youngsters in the neighborhood pursue college careers. That endeavor by the late Holcombe L. Rucker became the most storied summer basketball league ever.

title: Fortunes of Bosnian War Ease U.S. Military Tasks
description: Despite Western setbacks and miscalculations, the United States suddenly finds its risks in Bosnia greatly reduced.

title: Despite Final Score, the Positives Outweigh the Negatives
description: For a team that lost, the Jets found much to cheer about from their preseason game against the Giants.

title: New York, Through the Tour Bus Window: Germans; At the Shops, It's Bargain City
description: As the Gray Line bus slowed down in Chinatown, the passengers, all German and French speakers, were asked to step off. The tour guide told them they would have a few minutes to walk around the crowded streets and browse through the shops.

title: Most Wanted; Old and New Hits Lead the Lists
description: Three NBC television hits -- "Friends," "Seinfeld" and "E.R." -- finished at Nos. 1, 2 and 3, respectively, this week. These shows have been among the top 5 for 10 weeks, and on three occasions finished in the top three slots.

title: Versatile Hip-Hoppers With a Message of Belief
description: The Ghettoriginal hip-hop dancers have come a long way. The program they presented on Saturday night at Performance Space 122 was sleek and even slick. The energy of the city streets and clubs where hip-hop developed was never lost. But the Ghettoriginals could teach other dance companies a great deal about staging, brevity and connecting with an audience.

title: New York, Through the Tour Bus Window: Russians; Money, Money, Money, Money
description: Akh, the Russian's-eye view of New York! The enthusiasm, so long suppressed by hostile ideology! The swashbuckling tongue of Tolstoy, transforming chaos into sweeping generality! The disregard for truth when it gets in the way of poetry! The new love of lucre!

title: 2 Fire Island Houses Yield to Felix's Pull
description: Ron and Lucy Kerner bought their beachfront dream house last September. They refinished its wooden floors, installed new windows and added a new roof.

title: Americans Capture Two-Man Event
description: The Americans Stein Jorgensen and John Mooney won the two-man kayak at 200 meters yesterday at the world canoe and kayak championships in Duisburg, Germany. Jorgensen and Mooney, racing together for less than a year, took home the first United States gold medal in a major championship since 1988. (AP)

title: For Clinton and Family, a Vacation Of Golf, Hiking and Breathless Views
description: "I wish," the President of the United States said today, "we all had a moose."

title: Ban Nuclear Tests, in Virtual Reality Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sweep By the Mets Is Season's Highlight
description: It took 105 baseball games, but the Mets may have reached their finest moment of what has been a long and often torturous season. On a gorgeous afternoon at Shea Stadium with a crowd of 33,668 looking on, the youthful Mets did something that seemed improbable a few weeks ago.

title: Agassi's Winning Formula: Talent and a Lot of Luck
description: To beat Andre Agassi the way he has been playing this summer, a player must bang in frequent aces, attack the net for winning volleys, score with ground-stroke winners, rally well and not make too many errors.

title: 300 Killed and 400 Injured in a Train Wreck in India
description: About 300 people were killed and more than 400 were injured early today when a speeding passenger train in northern India plowed into another train that had stalled after hitting a cow, senior railroad officials said.

title: Fight Fans Are Quick To Voice Displeasure
description: Mike Tyson got $25 million.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. Midway through the afternoon session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 299.71 points, or 1.66 percent, to stand at 17,732.78. On Friday, the Nikkei lost 117.21 points.

title: Tyee in Alliance With Wunderman
description: The Tyee Group in Portland, Ore., which specializes in infomercials, and Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York, the direct marketing unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., have formed a strategic alliance under which Wunderman has bought a minority interest in Tyee. Though the terms were not disclosed, the two companies said Tyee would continue to operate independently under its current management and name.

title: Averting a Takeover of Schools; For Union City District, Efforts to Improve Seem to Work
description: There was a time a few years ago when Robert J. Fazio cringed before telling people he taught school here.

title: Marian Anderson Prize
description: Michelle DeYoung, a 27-year-old mezzo-soprano who grew up in Colorado and California, is the winner of the 1995 Marian Anderson Award, a $25,000 prize given annually to a singer who shows promise in recital, opera and oratorio repertory. Candidates do not know that they are being considered. This year's judges were the baritone William Warfield, the pianist John Wustman, the conductor and former music critic Will Crutchfield and Martin Feinstein, the former director of the Washington Opera. Ms. DeYoung has performed at the Metropolitan Opera since 1992, when she was a winner in the company's National Council Auditions. She has also sung at Glimmerglass Opera and at the Wolf Trap Opera.

title: Battle Lines Fade at Tanglewood
description: Even in circles as self-consciously tradition-bound as the classical music world, change is a necessary condition of life, its opposite being stagnation. Performers and musicologists refurbish their ideas about style regularly and have only lately (and grudgingly) made peace with the notion that their vaunted antiquarianism is itself a modernist stance. At the new-music end of the spectrum, things are more complicated. Composers have always searched restlessly for new sounds and forms, but after watching audiences drift away for decades, many are now reaching backward in the hope of giving listeners an impression of both novelty and familiarity.

title: The Doctor Left Free to Murder
description: Dr. David Benjamin finally got what he deserved earlier this month when a jury convicted him of murder for botching an abortion in 1993 and then callously letting the patient bleed to death. But it is appalling that Dr. Benjamin was still practicing years after health authorities began trying to revoke his license.

title: Article 691595 -- No Title
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced $29.2 million in grants for the third quarter of the year. New York State is to get $6.9 million, $6.6 million of which goes to arts institutions in New York City.

title: Have It Your Way, Professor: Custom Textbooks on Demand
description: Before the start of the fall term at Cornell University, Prof. Joan Piggott is expected to drop off at the university bookstore revisions to "Readings in Classical Japanese History," the text for one of the courses she teaches.

title: In Lead Cases, Only Negligence Makes New York City Liable; Why He Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Manager Manages To Be Farce's Fall Guy
description: IN the instant Vinny Vecchione made a poor judgment call and jumped into the ring, he fell into a most undistinguished role: fall guy for a farce.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Make Timber Jobs Last
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Sell Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, and auctions of new two-year notes on Tuesday and five-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Domestic Violence
description: By focusing attention on the problem of demestic violence, the O.J. Simpson case may have helped to spur legislation in the region and around the country. State legislatures in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have all passed domestic violence laws in the last year.

title: Two More Swans Are Killed
description: The question of who is killing off their prized swans is bedeviling the people who live near Upper Erskine Lake. Last summer, two young swans were found dead with broken necks, and last Friday, the bodies of the birds' parents were found, the A.P. reported.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: LITTLE LEAGUE New Jersey Team Loses

title: Becker and Bollettieri Split
description: Guilty of conspicuous consumption when it comes to the hiring and firing of tennis coaches, BORIS BECKER confirmed yesterday that his 18-month association with NICK BOLLETTIERI has ended. But unlike the mutually spiteful dissolution of Bollettieri's 10-year relationship with the top-ranked ANDRE AGASSI, this union has apparently ended amicably.

title: A Surprise For Clinton On Golf Tee
description: When President Clinton arrived at the practice tee of the Jackson Hole Golf and Tennis Club this morning, he found a swinging surprise from his wife, Hillary: Johnny Miller, the professional golfer and sports commentator, whom the First Lady had summoned to round out a foursome.

title: Brooke Group Ltd.(BGL,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jun 30
description: (Loss)The share earnings in the latest quarter were after giving effect to proportionate share of excess of carrying value of redeemable preferred shares over cost of shares purchased of $ 10.9 million.The company recorded an operating loss of $ 600,000 in the 1995 second quarter, compared with operating income of $ 7 million in the year-ago period.Brooke Group is a holding company which owns controlling interests in New Valley Corporation and Liggett Group Inc., and has tobacco and real estate operations in the former Soviet Union.

title: Low Bail to Be Sought In Killing
description: The authorities said they planned to ask at a hearing today that low bail be set for a 19-year-old Trenton woman who is accused of fatally stabbing her former boyfriend.

title: Unitog Co.(UTOG,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 30
description: Unitog said that the latest quarter rental revenue rose 16 percent as a result of internal growth from existing locations and acquisitions. The uniform rental concern said direct sales improved slightly in the latest second quarter as a result of higher sales of United States Postal Service garments.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHEP U.S.A., Park Ridge, N.J., a unit of Brambles Industries, named Bobby L. Moore president and chief executive. He succeeds Michael McCarthy, who will move to London to become chief executive of Chep in Europe. FIDELITY INVESTMENTS CO., Boston, a unit of FMR Corp., named Donald C. Holborn senior vice president and national sales planning manager of its institutional services company. QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP., Conshohocken, Pa., named Ronald J. Naples president and chief executive. TRISM INC., Fort Worth, appointed John J. Kilcullen president and chief operating officer. WESTIN HOTEL CO., Seattle, named Fred Kleisner to the new posts of president and chief operating officer.

title: New Random House Unit
description: Random House, a unit of Advance Publications, said yesterday that it had established a division to originate children's properties that can be licensed for development as books, toys, films and in other formats. Shane DeRolf was named president of the division, called Random House Entertainment. Mr. DeRolf will report to Harold Clarke, president of Random House's juvenile and merchandise group. The new division will work with other areas of the juvenile group on new products.

title: New York Times Names Vice President for Ad Sales
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it had appointed Daniel H. Cohen vice president for advertising sales.

title: A Free Shuttle Bus for Downtown Manhattan
description: Cynthia Welsh did not even have time to do the tourist's "Where am I?" head-swivel. No sooner had she stepped off a ferry from Hoboken, N.J., yesterday afternoon at the edge of Battery Park City than a small bus pulled up and took her, free of charge, to her destination, South Street Seaport.

title: A Paroled Killer Takes the Stand in His Rape Trial in Rockland
description: After three weeks of standing before the jury as his own lawyer, Reginald McFadden, a paroled killer from Pennsylvania who is charged with raping a 55-year-old South Nyack woman, finally got the chance he had been waiting for today.

title: Defendant Tells Terror Trial He Was Training for Bosnia
description: On the videotape, Tarig Elhassan is seen mixing fuel oil and fertilizer for what prosecutors say was a bomb. On an audio recording, he is heard discussing how long it would take to place bombs in a tunnel under the Hudson River and escape.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Cincinnati Bengals

title: ABC NEWS SETTLES SUITS ON TOBACCO
description: In an extraordinary act of contrition, ABC News publicly apologized last night for asserting in a news program that two giant tobacco companies add extra nicotine to their cigarettes.

title: Intel Shares Decline 7% as Analysts Trim Estimates on Earnings
description: Shares of the Intel Corporation fell 7.1 percent yesterday, after analysts at Oppenheimer & Company and Merrill Lynch trimmed their earnings estimates for the giant computer chip maker.

title: Molinari Fills Opening on School Board
description: Borough President Guy V. Molinari yesterday named Jerry Cammarata, a conservative local school board member and speech therapist, as Staten Island's representative to the central Board of Education -- just in time to weigh in on the selection of a new schools chancellor.

title: Sudan Oil Project Queries Cause Arakis Stock to Fall
description: Shares of the Arakis Energy Corporation plunged in Nasdaq trading yesterday as investors began to question the company's ambitious plans to finance a huge oil and pipeline project in the Sudan with funds from a little-known Saudi Arabian prince.

title: Mozart's Requiem Ends His Festival
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival ended its season at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening by singing its hero to his rest in a predictably reverential performance of his Requiem, led by the festival's music director, Gerard Schwarz. Although the work (like most, nowadays) is hardly new to these precincts, the timing may reflect a heightened preoccupation with mortality on the part of the festival itself, its season having been cut by Lincoln Center from seven weeks to four.

title: 34 Hurt as Queens Churchgoers and Police Clash
description: A melee between about 100 police officers and hundreds of parishioners broke out Sunday night at a Pentecostal church in South Jamaica, Queens, injuring 34 people and prompting the Mayor and the Police Commissioner to order an investigation into how the police handled the clash.

title: PHH Corp.(PHH,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Jul 31
CHRONICLE
description: People often ask her, and she often says no, but DEBORAH HARRY plans to appear in a benefit concert on Sept. 3 in Provincetown, Mass. The cause: an AIDS charity.

title: Chicago Jury Weighs Fate Of Lawmaker
description: The trial of Representative Mel Reynolds went to the jury today after prosecutors portrayed the Illinois Democrat as a man who used his position of esteem to lure a vulnerable 16-year-old girl into a sexual relationship.

title: Nike Agency Adds Leap to Its Roster
description: Nike Inc. has expanded its agency roster by naming the Leap Partnership in Chicago to handle creative assignments for its Niketown chain of retail stores, previously handled by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Aamco Leaves Ally & Gargano
description: Ally & Gargano of New York has lost a client, Aamco Transmissions Inc. of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. The agency's assignment for the automotive repair chain, on a project basis, had billings estimated at more than $15 million.

title: Executone Information Systems Inc. reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jun 30
description: b-Included a $ 44 million charge for restructuring: a $ 33.5 million goodwill impairment; an $ 8.8 million write-down of inventory, primarily service stock, relating to the impaired assets and other nonrecurring inventory adjustments; $ 900,000 related to the shut-down of the company's Arizona facility; and $ 800,000 of other miscellaneous charges. The period also included $ 1 million of expenses related to the attempted acquisition of the Dictaphone division of Pitney Bowes Inc.c-Net income(Loss)Executone Information Systems expects to record quarterly revenue of $ 78 million to $ 80 million for the balance of this year while it transitions its sales force.

title: Boeing Negotiating Big Order With China
description: The Boeing Company is negotiating the sale of several types of aircraft, including the new 777 twin-engine wide-body, to China's main international airline, company officials said today.

title: First to College, Then the Mill
description: After five years of study, William Weigel earned a master's degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Louisville in May. A few weeks later, he started work at a steel mill, running a machine that casts liquid steel into solid slabs.

title: Intriguing Promises From Apple
description: WINDOWS 95, the system software upgrade that will finally be released this week by the Microsoft Corporation, has a number of keen and spiffy new features that will delight anyone who has never used an Apple Macintosh.

title: Jurgen Schneider, 59, a Dancer, Instructor and Balletmaster
description: Jurgen Schneider, a teacher and balletmaster at American Ballet Theater, the Stuttgart Ballet and the Royal Ballet, drowned on Aug. 15 in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 59.

title: Following Welfare Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Privatize City Jails? Here's The Hitch
description: Throughout his administration, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has unleashed a blizzard of declarations about privatizing government. All have had zeal and purpose, but few have been accompanied by specific plans and verified savings. One of the least plausible is the Mayor's recent proposal to privatize the New York City Department of Correction.

title: A Former Governor Cancels Radio Show
description: L. Douglas Wilder, a former Virginia Governor and onetime Presidential candidate who was part of a wave of unemployed politicians who started radio talk shows this year, today canceled his program, which had never made money or found a national audience.

title: The frontier in movie promotion is -- you guessed it -- the Internet. But will it help the box office?
description: MAKE no mistake about it: Hollywood has found a new star.

title: TWO WEST VIRGINIA BANKS AGREE TO COMBINATION
description: United Bankshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Eagle Bancorp Inc. for about $93 million in stock. The combined companies would have more than $2.2 billion in assets. Under the agreement, each of Eagle's 2.7 million shares would be exchanged for 1.15 shares of United Bankshares. Eagle, which is based in Charleston, W. Va., has about $384 million in assets and 11 branches in West Virginia. United Bankshares, which is based in Petersburg, W. Va., has $1.8 billion in assets and 39 offices in West Virginia and one in Virginia.

title: The Chaff in Iowa's Straw Poll
description: These being the dog days of summer, the Republican Presidential straw poll in Ames, Iowa, last Saturday got a lot of attention. Senator Phil Gramm ran dead even with the front-runner for the G.O.P. nomination, Senator Bob Dole, and for a moment there we were fooled into thinking something momentous had occurred.

title: Sadness and Shame at The Citadel
description: When Shannon Faulkner took on the task of becoming the first female student at The Citadel, South Carolina's all-male military college, she also took on a broader responsibility. Like it or not, she was acting not only for herself but for all other Americans who believe that a school financed by taxpayers' money has no right to discriminate on the basis of gender.

title: Decline in Federal Spending Narrows U.S. Budget Deficit
description: The Federal budget deficit narrowed in July from a year earlier as Government spending slowed and revenue increased, the Treasury said today.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Post Drop of 1.9% on Big Board
description: The peak in Big Board short interest occurred in early June, when it hit 2.05 billion shares, after the stock market had been recording steady gains.

title: Moody's Lowers Many Japanese Bank Ratings
description: In a blow to the nation's already battered financial institutions, Moody's Investors Service announced a new set of weaker ratings for Japanese banks today that in part reflected the heavy burden of bad debt many are carrying.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Sean Ryan, one of two Mount Rainier park rangers who fell to their death while attempting to rescue an injured climber, incorrectly described his father, an oceanographer. It was Sean Ryan, not his father, who participated in a marine geology program in Barbados.

title: LILLY DETAILS PLAN TO SEPARATE UNITS IN STOCK SWAP
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that its shareholders would receive 3.49 shares of common stock of the Guidant Corporation for each Lilly share tendered in a stock swap valued at up to $1.26 billion. Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis, said in January 1994 that it would separate its nine units that provide medical devices and diagnostics equipment from its drug business, on which it will concentrate. Guidant is made up of five of the nine businesses. Under the offer, which expires on Sept. 18, Lilly will offer the exchange for up to 16.5 million of its shares. A minimum of about 8.3 million Lilly shares must be tendered or the offer will be withdrawn, Lilly said.

title: Trans World Entertainment Corp.(TWMC,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 29
description: (Loss)The results included 13 weeks of operations.

title: Market Place; After the Upjohn deal, takeover talk turns to Warner-Lambert.
description: WITH every new drug company merger in the last few years has come speculation about which company will be the next target. One by one, the rumored candidates have been picked off -- with the Warner-Lambert Company as the main exception.

title: Heat's No. 1 Draft Pick Sounds About Right to Knicks
description: The Knicks are willing to release Pat Riley from the final year of his contract provided that the Miami Heat grants their one wish: Give us one of your two 1996 first-round draft picks, the Knicks say, and we will gladly give you the right to negotiate with the sport's most successful coach over the past two decades.

title: SONY AND SHARP PICK C-CUBE'S CHIPS, LIFTING ITS STOCK
description: Shares of C-Cube Microsystems Inc. rose 10 percent yesterday after the computer chip maker said the Sony Corporation and Sharp Electronics would use its technology for new entertainment products. Sony selected C-Cube chips for a new line of video compact disk players. And Sharp Electronics, which is owned by the Sharp Corporation, picked C-Cube to provide the technology for a new portable entertainment system. C-Cube, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., makes chips used in the compression of video clips for games and computers. The company's stock rose $4, to $44, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Two More Officials Leave Bear, Stearns
description: Two senior managing directors have resigned from Bear, Stearns & Company, bringing to six the number of senior executives to leave the firm since May.

title: Accounts
description: * Cellular One of Rhode Island and Bristol County, Warwick, R.I., a unit of Southern New England Telecommunications, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, as the first agency to handle its account. The billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

title: 100 ARE WOUNDED
description: A suicide bomber struck once again inside Israel today, killing four passengers and himself and wounding about 100 others in a Jerusalem bus, and touching off angry daylong protests against the Israeli Government's negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Jets Learn It Is Better to Receive Than Pass Up
description: After deciding that receivers Stevie Anderson and Orlando Parker -- who had 10 catches between them last season -- could not catch an I.R.T., the Jets released them yesterday. Now the Jets are in the market for a veteran receiver.

title: Women's Rights, Human Rights
description: Voices are growing louder in Washington against American participation in the United Nations Conference on Women in Beijing next month. Powerful Republicans say Hillary Rodham Clinton's participation would lend credibility to a repressive regime. They say Washington should refuse to send a delegation at all, to punish China for its human rights record.

title: From the 'Old School' of Hip-Hop
description: Hip-hop has been around long enough to have its own "old school," now the name of the bare-bones style that emerged from South Bronx parties in the late 1970's. Disk jockeys strung together funk records, rappers came up with rhymes and break-dancers translated the beat into gymnastic spins, all of them sublimating rivalry into displays of skill. "I make ultimatums for the fun of it," KRS-One rapped on Friday night at "Old School Throwdown III" at the Paramount.

title: By Design; Long, Leggy and Slim
description: The trendy young neo-mods may be wearing hip-hugging flared pants, but the rest of the fashion world favors stovepipe-leg pants that fit flat across the stomach. Some are cropped above the ankle like capri pants, and others reach the tops of shoes, but they all make the wearer look slim and long-legged. By far the most popular style shown for fall and resort, the pants are already in stores.

title: Jets Look Deep and Cut 3 Receivers
description: In an unexpected move, the Jets cut 16 players today -- including three young wide receivers -- and Coach Rich Kotite said the team was in the market for an experienced receiver.

title: In Steppe and Desert, U.N. Seeks to Protect Mongolia Environment
description: THE Gobi Desert, where rainfall averages fewer than two inches a year and winds whip the dust up to 90 miles per hour for days at a time, is one of the most desolate places on earth. Twice the size of Texas, the Gobi ranks as the coldest and northernmost desert. Temperatures ricochet from 100 degrees Fahrenheit to minus 16. Only a small number of nomads live there and few Westerners have crossed it.

title: Neuron Talks to Chip, And Chip to Nerve Cell
description: ALTHOUGH prosthetic surgeons dream of replacing severed limbs with mechanical surrogates controlled directly by the living nervous system, the creation of "bionic" hybrids like Darth Vader of "Star Wars" and the Six Million-Dollar Man remains purely imaginary. But a team of German biophysicists has now taken a small step toward mating man and machine by opening a two-way communication link between a silicon chip and a leech's nerve cell.

title: Ottoman Art: Seeking A Robust Image
description: For all the size, wealth and longevity of the Ottoman empire, its place in history has been strangely insecure, undermined not only by its 19th-century image as "the sick man of Europe," but also by modern Turkey's determination this century to be recognized as part of Western civilization.

title: Scientists Are Puzzled Over the Deaths of Whales in the St. Lawrence
description: THE Gulf of St. Lawrence, drainage basin for more than 500,000 square miles of industrial Canada and the United States, is also the world's longest, widest and deepest estuary, home to whales, dolphins and seabirds. It is a place where economic and ecological interests meet, and scientists concerned with both have been studying such questions as why the population of beluga whales here is not increasing despite a ban on hunting them.

title: Bullying Taiwan
description: China has embarked on an escalating campaign of military maneuvers meant to intimidate Taiwan and undermine its President, Lee Teng-hui. Washington, as much as it wants to calm troubled relations with Beijing, must firmly signal its opposition to this campaign. Ties with China cannot be built on tolerance for provocative displays of military force and efforts to destabilize Taiwan.

title: A New and Deadly Fad Comes Riding Into Town
description: Teen-age joy riders call it "car-surfing." A couple sit on the hood of a car and lean back against the windshield as a friend races the car down the road.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Friday, about the naming of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg by Himmel Nutrition Inc. to handle advertising for the Ovaltine line of milk additives, misstated the scope of the assignment. Avrett, Free will handle the creative portion of the account; the media planning and buying portion will continue to be handled by Himmel.

title: Heavy Volcanic Eras Were Caused By Plumes From the Earth's Core
description: GEOLOGISTS on the trail of a rare isotope of helium have stumbled on a remarkable finding about the outpourings of lava that every few millions of years or so inundate vast regions of the planet with a sea of fiery rock.

title: Judge Clears Antitrust Pact For Microsoft
description: A central chapter in the Government's investigation of the Microsoft Corporation was finally closed yesterday, when a Federal judge approved the Justice Department's 1994 antitrust settlement with the company.

title: Bosnian Splinter Group Is Exiled and Unwanted
description: In six years, Robert Karajic, 24, has served in four armies.

title: Casting an Ear on Bela Bartok
description: When nearly 400 people, most of them just average concertgoers, fill a college auditorium on a Saturday morning in the summer to attend a discussion and demonstration of the "Evolution of Violin Technique in the 20th Century," something significant in terms of classical music programming is happening. This event was just one of 14 presented over the last two weekends as part of the Bard Music Festival's examination of "Bela Bartok and His World." For the sixth consecutive year, this Rediscovery, as the festivals are called, was presided over by Leon Botstein, who is the president of Bard College. There were chamber music and choral concerts, thought-provoking panels, pre-concert lectures and two full programs by the American Symphony Orchestra led by Mr. Botstein, the orchestra's music director.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column in the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about the unveiling of a set of commemorative dinosaur postage stamps at the Peabody Museum in New Haven misstated the date. The event has been called off because the Postal Service postponed release of the stamps.

title: A Court Asks That a New Jury Reconsider a Death Penalty
description: A man who killed his father, then 21 years later killed his former wife and son, has been spared the death penalty, at least for now.

title: Hills Stores Co.(HDS,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 29
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 35.6 million, or $ 3.65 a share, related to severance and refinancing expenses.c-Included a gain of $ 4.5 million related to elimination of the company's pension-benefit obligation.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.(Loss)

title: In Assisted Suicide, Body Is Left Near Hospital
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian attended his 25th suicide early today, but in a new twist, the body was left in the back seat of a car in a doctors' parking lot outside the emergency room of one of Michigan's largest hospitals.

title: N.B.A. Dissidents Give Opinion
description: The 16 players who have filed an antitrust lawsuit against the National Basketball Association have told their colleagues that the owners "fooled the union leadership again" in the latest tentative labor agreement.

title: Patterns
description: Donna Karan Times 13

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7 BOMB KILLS 4 IN JERUSALEM A suicide bomber struck a Jerusalem bus, killing four people and wounding about 100 others. A militant Palestinian group claimed responsibility. The bombing set off protests against talks for Palestinians for self-rule. A1 An American teacher died in the Jerusalem bombing. A6 TRIBUTE AFTER BOSNIA DEATHS Americans paid tribute to the three United States officials killed in an accident while on a peace mission in Bosnian, and their colleagues pledged to complete their mission successfully. A1 BOSNIA'S FORGOTTEN REFUGEES A group of 25,000 Bosnian Muslims, followers of a dissident allied with the Serbs, were forced into Croatia as a Serb siege was broken. Now they are refugees, reflecting the Balkan war's complexities. A7 DIVORCE SURGES IN CHINA China's society is undergoing a profound change, with a surge in divorce reflecting rapid economic growth that is causing new hopes and fears and with less Government interference in personal lives. A1 MORE CHECHNYA FIGHTING Russian troops retook a police station in Chechnya that had been seized by Chechen separatist rebels, which appeared to be a severe setback in the fragile peace process for the region. A3 RWANDA REFUGEES FORCED OUT Zaire forced several thousand Rwandan refugees out of refugee camps and back across the border, causing thousands of other refugees to flee the camps because they fear reprisals if they return home. A2 India searched for the signalman who fled after a rail disaster. A5 Avignon Journal: Begging nomads get their hands slapped. A4 National A8-13 ABC SETTLES TOBACCO SUITS ABC News apologized for asserting in a news program that two large tobacco companies add extra nicotine to their cigarettes. A1

title: The Burden of Proof
description: To the Editor:

title: New Officer Named At Riney Agency
description: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco said yesterday that Scott Marshall would join the agency on Sept. 5 in the new position of president, assuming responsibilities from Hal Riney, chairman and chief executive, who has been unofficially serving as president for the last three years. Mr. Marshall, 42 was previously president of Scattergood, a high-technology marketing agency in Seattle; before that he was president and chief creative officer of Cole & Weber in Seattle, which is owned by the WPP Group.

title: I.M.F. Blames Mexicans for Flight of Peso
description: The collapse of the Mexican peso last winter came after Mexican investors sent billions of dollars out of the country, the International Monetary Fund has concluded.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CLASH HURTS OFFICERS AND CHURCHGOERS A melee between about a hundred police officers and hundreds of parishioners broke out after a revival meeting at a Pentecostal church in South Jamaica, Queens. By the time the standoff was over, 28 churchgoers and 6 officers had been hurt. [ Page A1. ] KOREAN IMMIGRANTS RETURN HOME Over the last two decades, the entrepreneurial energy of Korean immigrants transformed neighborhoods in New York and other cities. Now, with Korea's economy burgeoning, thousands are returning to their homeland. [ A1. ] NEW YORK CITY MORE CHARGES FOR AN OFFICER A Bronx police officer already awaiting trial in the death of a Florida man was arrested and charged with assaulting a 16-year-old youth whom he apprehended for recklessly riding a go-cart in 1993. [ B3. ] MAN CHARGED IN ARSON FIRE IN BROOKLYN A fire raced through five wood-frame houses in East New York, Brooklyn. A resident was charged with setting it. [ B3. ] A FREE SHUTTLE BUS STARTS IN MANHATTAN It was the first day of operations for the Downtown Loop, which city officials and downtown merchants bill as the city's first regularly scheduled free bus shuttle service. [ B3. ] HEVESI SAYS AGENCY BARRED AUDITS The City Comptroller charged that the city's Human Resources Administration had improperly barred his staff from conducting unannounced investigations at six of the agency's group homes for foster children. [ B3. ] SHORTER SCHOOL DAY WORRIES OFFICIALS State education officials expressed serious concerns about a request by the city's Board of Education to allow school districts to shorten the elementary school day. [ B4. ] A defendant denied a charge that he plotted to bomb New York City targets. [ B2. ] REGION 'CAR SURFING' KILLS A WOMAN Teen-age joy riders call it "car-surfing." A couple sit on the hood of a car and lean back against the windshield as a friend races the car down the road. It is a fad that the police were unaware of until it claimed the life of an 18-year-old Hauppauge woman on Sunday. [ B5. ] 2 TEEN-AGERS CHARGED IN DART ATTACKS Two teen-agers were charged with one of three attacks with blowgun darts in Massapequa, L.I., that occurred over the last six weeks. [ B5. ] A JURY WILL REVIEW A DEATH SENTENCE A man who killed his father, then 21 years later killed his former wife and son, has been spared the death penalty, at least for now, by a State Supreme Court ruling in Connecticut. [ B5. ] JUDGE ENDS A PRISONER'S ISOLATION A Federal judge has ruled that a murderer kept in solitary confinement for three and a half years because he refused to take a tuberculosis test must be put back into a regular cell at the Attica Correctional Facility. [ B5. ] One victim of a bombing in Israel was a teacher in Woodbridge, Conn. [ International Report, page A6. ] Chronicle B2 Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves B5

title: International Briefs; German Outlook Dims
description: New figures on the German economy were announced yesterday that prompted economists to say the country's growth outlook was darkening again. The Economics Ministry said industrial orders fell 3.5 percent in June from May after a 3 percent rise in May from April. The Federal Statistics Office said western German producer prices fell one-tenth of a percent in July from June, the first fall since September. Prices were up 1.9 percent from July 1994. In Munich, the economic research institute Ifo said its monthly business confidence index fell to 97.5 in July from 99 in June, its lowest level in 15 months. (Reuters)

title: International Briefs; Asda to Buy Out Partner
description: The British retailer Asda Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy out its joint venture partner British Aerospace P.L.C. in their Burwood House retail property company for $:88 million ($136 million). Asda said it would also take over Burwood's debt of $:265 million ($409 million). The deal gives Asda ownership control of 34 of its own stores and 4 shopping centers and helps British Aerospace end its ill-fated flirtation with property development, which it started six years ago. (Reuters)

title: For Now, Judge Ito Defers Defense Request on Tapes
description: Judge Lance A. Ito today rejected the inventory of racial epithets, expletives and purported admissions of misconduct that O. J. Simpson's lawyers culled from a screenwriter's taped interviews with Detective Mark Fuhrman, saying the defense motion was so filled with mistakes as to be incoherent.

title: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, 84, Is Dead; Noble Laureate Uncovered 'White Dwarfs'
description: Dr. Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, a Nobel laureate in physics whose discovery about the evolution of stars pointed toward the existence of "black holes," died yesterday at the University of Chicago Hospitals. He was 84 and lived in Chicago.

title: INSIDE
description: School Board Seat Filled

title: Healthy Korean Economy Draws Immigrants Home
description: Four years ago, Chang Hyeok Soo began making plans to leave Korea and move to the United States. He wanted to echo the success of his sister and brother-in-law, who had built a comfortable home in New Jersey and a thriving trading company in Manhattan.

title: Endangered Clapper Rails Making a Recovery
description: AFTER a brush with disaster caused by the wily red fox, the endangered California clapper rail is rebounding in the salt marshes of south San Francisco Bay, the bird's last stronghold.

title: A Gambler of Passion and Mystery
description: Herve Filion pushed himself like no other harness driver around. Even after 40 years in the sport and a place in the Hall of Fame, he continued to race as often as 50 times a week. No one seemed to have a prayer of matching his record of victories -- 14,783 -- as long as the 55-year-old driver kept up that grueling pace.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL TO MAKE NOMINATIONS FOR ELCO BOARD
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc., whose takeover bid of $27 a share for Elco Industries was snubbed last week, said yesterday that it planned to nominate three people who would support the merger to serve on Elco's board. Illinois Tool, of Glenview, Ill., whose products include construction fasteners and packaging systems, said it would request a list of Elco's stockholders so it could solicit support for its offer. The three directors would make up a third of Elco's nine-member board. Elco, a maker of metal and plastic parts and fasteners, is based in Rockford, Ill. At the time Illinois Tool's $131.6 million offer was made on Aug. 10, the stock of Elco was priced at $19.25 a share. It closed yesterday at $31.75, up 43.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Can Parochial Schools Teach Public Schools?; Small Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Fourstardave May Be Retired
description: In the 100th and maybe final race of his long career, Fourstardave failed today to extend his streak of winning at least once a year for eight years at Saratoga. Instead, the 10-year-old gelding finished fifth in an allowance race for his second loss of the Saratoga season, with one week remaining.

title: Turner Board Won't Make Bid For King World
description: Turner Broadcasting System said yesterday that its board had decided against buying King World Productions.

title: Newark Gets $2.9 Million in Aid
description: City officials were disappointed last year when Federal officials did not choose Newark as an urban empowerment zone, which would have brought in $100 million for economic development. But yesterday, the city received a consolation prize: $2.9 million in Federal aid and a designation as a Federal "enterprise community."

title: Price of Crude Oil Climbs Again On Trader Concerns About Iraq
description: Crude oil prices rose yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as traders grew increasingly concerned about potential political instability in Iraq.

title: Under Technology-Stock Pressure, the Market Closes Weakly
description: The stock market opened yesterday with a bang, but closed with a whimper.

title: Hevesi Says H.R.A. Barred Spot Audit of Foster Homes
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi charged yesterday that the city's Human Resources Administration had improperly barred his staff from conducting unannounced investigations at six of the agency's group homes for foster children.

title: Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corp.(OSCH,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 30
As You Light That Cigar Remember the Migrant Farm Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillies Extend Fregosi's Contract
description: JIM FREGOSI will return as the manager of the Philadelphia Phillies next season, the team announced yesterday. Fregosi's future was the subject of intense speculation ever since the Phillies plummeted from a 37-18 record and a five-game lead in the National League East on June 25 to their present record of 54-53, 12 1/2 games behind the first-place Atlanta Braves.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about a Bronx police officer accused of shooting and killing a friend incorrectly described the injuries that the officer, Cathleen Byrnes, apparently suffered in a scuffle before the shooting. According to a neighbor's account, it was her wrists, not her ribs, that were swollen and red. The article also misstated the year when Officer Byrnes's service revolver was temporarily taken away because of concerns over her erratic behavior. It was 1987, not 1990.

title: Can Parochial Schools Teach Public Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Parent & Child column in The Home Section on Thursday, about recordings for children by established rock, pop, country and R & B singers, referred to the mandolinist David Grisman incorrectly. He and Jerry Garcia were collaborators, but Mr. Grisman was never a member of the Grateful Dead.

title: M. W. Chenault, 44, Gunman Who Killed Mother of Dr. King
description: Marcus Wayne Chenault Jr., who killed the mother of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Sunday service in Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta in 1974, died on Saturday at a hospital in the Atlanta suburb of Riverdale. He was 44.

title: A Trial (Not Simpson's) on Court TV
description: Who says Court TV carries nothing but the O. J. Simpson trial? It's a darn canard. Other cases are always being squeezed in during off days and off hours, and some are newsworthy. Tonight, for example, comes "Prozac on Trial," an hourlong look at the first civil suit against the Eli Lilly Company, makers of the world's most popular feel-good drug, for its allegedly dire effects on one consumer. The fact that Prozac now brings Eli Lilly around $1.6 billion a year lends a certain weight to the proceedings.

title: Tadiran Ltd.(TAD,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jun 30
description: Tadiran said sales for all segments rose for the latest second quarter, driven by Tadiran Telecommunications Ltd., Tadiran Electrical Appliances Ltd. and Advanced Technology Ltd., which were increased by higher exports.

title: How's Sierra Doing? Showalter Hedges Opinion
description: So far. Buck Showalter uttered the phrase over and over today while discussing Ruben Sierra's brief tenure with the Yankees, as in, so far, there hasn't been any trouble and, so far, he hasn't angered us with his behavior.

title: Chess
description: The members of the charmed circle are, of course, the Professional Chess Association's champion, Gary Kasparov of Russia, and his challenger, Viswanathan Anand of India, along with the International Chess Federation's champion, Anatoly Karpov of Russia, and his challenger, Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Night column on Sunday about the Taste of the Hamptons benefit for the Family Service League of Suffolk County on Aug. 12 misspelled the last name of a guest who is a host of "TV Diners" on the TV Food Network. She is Nina Griscom, not Griscomb.

title: U.S. Industries Oppose Emission Proposals
description: American manufacturers are urging the Clinton Administration not to make any early new commitment to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other "greenhouse gases" as a new round of international talks begins in Geneva.

title: State Questions Plan to Cut School Day
description: State education officials have serious concerns about a request by the New York City Board of Education to allow school districts to shorten the elementary school day, a linchpin of the districts' efforts to pare $72 million from their budgets, a spokesman for the state Department of Education said yesterday.

title: Untold Story in Primates Lab Transfer
description: To the Editor:

title: George Bekefi, 70, Physics Researcher
description: George Bekefi, a teacher and researcher known for his contributions to plasma physics, particularly in the field of extremely high-power microwave generators, died last Thursday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 70.

title: Review/Fashion; Setting Swimsuits Free
description: The love affair between the swimsuit and the push-up bra is over. In presentations last week for the cruise 1996 season, designers showed a return to elegance as well as the athletic influence that has seeped into bathing suits in the last few years. Athletic-style swimwear should have particular appeal next year since the height of the suit-buying season will coincide with the Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

title: Who Must Tyson Face Next? A Finer Brand of Tomato Can
description: If you paid $45.95 for Saturday's Mike Tyson fight, and you felt ripped off, even astonished by its brevity, you must have ignored all we knew about how undeserving a challenger Peter McNeeley was. He was a hurricane without an eye. Other tomato cans are insulted when stacked on a shelf beside him.

title: Officer Charged in a Death Is Accused in Assault Case
description: A Bronx police officer already awaiting trial in the death of a Florida man was arrested and charged yesterday with assaulting a 16-year-old boy whom he apprehended for recklessly riding a go-cart in 1993.

title: Lawyers Told To Offer Way To Shield Jury In Bomb Case
description: The judge in the Oklahoma City bombing case today ordered lawyers for the prosecution and the defense to propose ways to shield the trial jury from outside interference and avoid sequestration.

title: 2 Robberies on Casino Floors
description: The state police said yesterday that one man may have been responsible for two robberies that occurred on crowded casino floors two days apart. In the latest incident, at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino on Sunday, a gunman grabbed $220 in cash from a woman who makes change and fled, Trooper Al Della Fave said. On Friday, a woman who performs the same duties at the Showboat Casino Hotel was robbed of $250, the A.P. reported.

title: Return of the Champions
description: Two of the hardest hitters in sports were back in competition over the weekend after long absences, but what a difference there was in the return engagements. Mike Tyson resumed his boxing career in a ludicrous bout that further disgraced his sport, while Monica Seles won a clean, commanding victory that signaled she is ready to regain her position as the best woman player in the world.

title: Can Parochial Schools Teach Public Schools?; Vouchers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Revenge of the Studio System
description: The foxes are finally in the Hollywood chicken coop, or at least one might be excused for thinking so. Sylvester Stallone signed a reported three-picture, $60 million contract at MCA/Universal shortly after his former agent, Ron Meyer, was picked to run the studio. And one can only imagine what the installation of the world's most powerful agent, Michael Ovitz, as the chief executive at Disney might portend for his old clients.

title: Employee Is Charged With Theft
description: A financial analyst was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing $667,000 from his employer, Exxon Research and Engineering Company in Florham Park, the Morris County Prosecutor's office said.

title: People's Bank To North Castle
description: People's Bank in Bridgeport, Conn., a unit of People's Mutual Holding, has named North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn., to handle its account, which had been at the TBWA Advertising unit of the Omnicom Group in New York for the last seven years. The billings were estimated at more than $6 million.

title: Doctors' Groups Sue Aetna Over Health Care Contracts
description: Groups of doctors at three Long Island hospitals filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday accusing the Aetna Life and Casualty Company of violating antitrust laws by putting pressure on the doctors to sign contracts that would make them part of Aetna's health care plan on Long Island.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Perhaps TONY DANZA thinks he is actually Sean Penn?

title: Man Is Charged In Arson Fire In Brooklyn
description: Had it not been for the fact that almost everyone was outside enjoying the weather, the fire would have been deadly.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 1997 through Salomon Brothers. The noncallable issue is priced at par to yield 6.07 percent.

title: Yes, Motherhood Lowers Pay
description: My tax return for 1991, the year my first child was born, shows that I earned a whopping $800. Fortunately, my husband earned somewhat more that year. We were not sent to the workhouse. But did my lack of income make me "unequal" to him?

title: O. J. Initial Is Embroiled in Case
description: An appeals court yesterday upheld the conviction of a Dunellen man who spent five days in jail last year after a judge said he had threatened his wife by writing the initials "O. J." on two child-support checks.

title: Isolation Ends For Prisoner Who Refused Testing for TB
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a murderer kept in solitary confinement for three and a half years because he refused to take a tuberculosis test must be put back into a regular cell at the Attica Correctional Facility.

title: 2 Youths Accused in Shooting Of Steel Dart Into Girl's Back
description: Two teen-agers were charged today with one of three dart attacks here in the last six weeks.

title: Long Road To The Slots; By Train and Ferry, Bettors Cross The Sound to Connecticut's Casino
description: Stu Glass woke up on a Wednesday in early August at the crack of dawn, spent five hours making the pilgrimage from his home on Long Island to the Foxwoods Casino here in the hills of eastern Connecticut, lost $20 on the slot machines and called it fun.

title: Deal by Reader's Digest
description: The Canadian unit of Reader's Digest Association Inc. said today that it had acquired the 50 percent of Quality Service Programs Inc. it did not already own from Maclean Hunter Publishing Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. Reader's Digest said Quality Service Programs helps Canadian school children raise money for educational-enrichment programs by selling magazine subscriptions and gifts. Reader's Digest Canada had owned 50 percent of Quality Service Programs since 1973.

title: A Teacher Who Taught With Love
description: Joan Davenny, the American killed in yesterday's suicide bombing aboard a Jerusalem bus, had arrived in Israel a few weeks ago to study Jewish history and culture, which she taught at two schools in Woodbridge, Conn., friends and school officials said last night.

title: Harnischfeger Industries(HPH,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Jul 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 4,827,000, or 11 cents a share, from early retirement of debt and a loss of $ 200,000 from discontinued operations.Results for the latest quarter and year-ago period were restated to reflect Joy Environmental as a discontinued operation.Results for the year-ago quarter are also restated to include the results of Joy Technologies Inc.Revenues are total revenues.

title: U.S. ROBOTICS BUYS ISDN SYSTEMS FOR ABOUT $40 MILLION
description: The U.S. Robotics Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held ISDN Systems Corporation of Vienna, Va., in a stock swap valued at about $40 million. The move expands the presence of U.S. Robotics in the growing market for integrated services digital network, or I.S.D.N., technology, which allows voice and video data to be sent over the same phone line simultaneously. The shares of U.S. Robotics, which is based in Skokie, Ill., closed down $7.875, at $150.75, on Nasdaq. The stocks of U.S. Robotics and other technology companies fell after Oppenheimer & Co. lowered earnings estimates on the Intel Corporation, the maker of semiconductors, creating concern about profitability in that industry and in the personal computer business.

title: Kraft Sets Review For Grape-Nuts Job
description: The Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it had placed in review its Post Grape-Nuts cereal account, which has been handled by Grey Advertising in New York since 1980. The billings were estimated at $25 million to $27 million.

title: A Lemon Law on Wheelchairs
description: A motorized wheelchair can cost up to $15,000, but until now, there has been little protection for the consumer who winds up with a lemon. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday requiring makers of motorized wheelchairs to provide a one-year warranty and to give customers a choice between a replacement chair or cash if the lemon cannot be fixed. "This new law will help to ease the burden of additional cost, delay and gross disadvantage to those who rely on wheelchairs for mobility," The Associated Press quoted one of the sponsors, Assemblyman Anthony Impreveduto, Democrat of Secaucus, as saying.

title: Rangers and Zubov Reach New Terms
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they had reached terms on a new contract with Sergei Zubov, the Russian defenseman who was ninth in total points among National Hockey League defensemen last season. Terms were not disclosed.

title: International Briefs; Axa Confirms Talks Over Orcofi
description: The French insurer Axa S.A. confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Orcofi, a company headed by Henri Racamier, the former chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton S.A.; Orcofi comprises various businesses owned by the Vuitton family. According to the weekly financial magazine Le Nouvel Economiste, Axa will acquire a shell company whose only assets will be 3 billion francs ($600 million) in cash, resulting from the sale of LVMH stock.

title: Ex-Senator in Plea Agreement on Ethics Charges
description: David F. Durenberger, a former Republican Senator from Minnesota who spent his last years in office fighting a host of ethics charges, has agreed to plead guilty to five counts involving cheating on his Senate expense account, Justice Department officials said today.

title: Riesenberg Is Latest Giant To Fall
description: The Giants received crushing news yesterday when it was learned that offensive tackle Doug Riesenberg had a damaged posterior cruciate knee ligament. He will likely miss the season opener against the Dallas Cowboys and could be sidelined a month.

title: 25 Survive Plane Crash In Georgia
description: Twenty-five of the 29 people aboard a Delta commuter airplane survived a fiery crash landing in a west Georgia hayfield today after the plane apparently lost an engine in midflight.

title: Officer Charged in a Death Is Accused of an Assault
description: A Bronx police officer already awaiting trial in the death of a Florida man was arrested and charged yesterday with assaulting a 16-year-old boy whom he apprehended for recklessly riding a go-cart in 1993.

title: International Briefs; Mannesmann Shifts To First-Half Profit
description: The German engineering and technology company Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that it had a profit of 141 million marks ($95 million) for the first half after a loss of 27 million ($18.3 million) for the corresponding period a year earlier. The company said its profit and sales would continue to rise during the second half and that full-year levels would be higher than in 1994, when net profit surged to 340 million marks ($230.4 million) after a loss of 513 million ($347.7 million) in 1993, Mannesmann's worst year ever.

title: Woods Sets Out to Defend Title
description: TIGER WOODS of Cypress, Calif., the youngest golfer to win the United States Amateur championship, will try to become the first champion in 12 years to successfully defend his title when the centennial edition of the tournament begins today at Newport Country Club on the same course that played host to the first amateur championship in 1895.

title: In the World of Fonts
description: MANY office workers produce documents that are printed or shown directly on a computer screen. For either purpose, a judicious inventory of fonts is desirable. But whether Windows or the Macintosh Operating System is in use, fonts get out of hand. Several come with the system, more accompany word processors and other applications, others are supplied with printers, and at least hundreds are available elsewhere.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HUBCO INC., Union City, N.J., a bank holding company, plans to acquire Growth Financial Corp., Basking Ridge, N.J., for $14.64 a share, in a stock swap valued at about $24.7 million. PURE TECH INTERNATIONAL INC., Ridgefield, N.J., which makes plastic products, completed its acquisition of a resins plant from Occidental Chemical Corp., Dallas, a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum Corp., for $28 million. TOY BIZ INC., New York, a toy maker, said it planned to acquire some of the assets of Spectra Star Inc., Yuma, Ariz., a maker of kites, yo-yos, marbles and flying disks. Terms were not disclosed. TRITON ENERGY CORP., Dallas, an oil and gas exploration concern, said it received $16 million in cash from the sale of its petroleum assets in France to Coparex International S.A., a French oil and gas company.

title: No Headline
description: "My husband was a good worker, a good son to his parents, a good father to his son, and a terrible husband. That's what our society teaches men to do." LAN DING, divorced Chinese tailor. [ A6:5 ]

title: Judges Fines Du Pont $115 Million for Concealing Trial Evidence
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company was fined $115 million today by a Federal judge for concealing evidence in a 1993 trial about the plant damage its Benlate fungicide may have caused.

title: RETAILER IN JAPAN TO SELL PACKARD BELL COMPUTERS
description: Daiei Inc., Japan's largest chain retailer, said yesterday that it would sell personal computers made by Packard Bell Electronics Inc. of Sacramento, Calif. The agreement calls for Daiei to begin selling Packard Bell's Force 75cdx desktop personal computers at 250 of its affiliated stores in Japan beginning Sept. 1, at a price of 188,000 yen, or about $1,940. Personal computers priced at less than 200,000 yen are considered "low cost" in Japan, and foreign makers have made significant inroads into this part of the market.

title: Bombardier Inc. reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.Bombardier Inc. can be found on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges using the ticker symbol, BBD.B.

description: In percent

title: Philip Semark, 49, Arts Administrator
description: Philip Semark, an arts administrator and a founder of Dance U.S.A., a service organization, died on Thursday at Sayville Hospital on Long Island. He was 49 and lived in Occidental, Calif.

title: International Briefs; Qantas Stock Ownership
description: Qantas Airways said yesterday that foreigners held 52 percent of the shares of the carrier, Australia's national airline, whose stock was recently offered to the public. The percentage of stock held by foreigners exceeds the limit set by Australian laws. Qantas said foreign investors had bought 31.1 million shares too many, surpassing a 49 percent ceiling on foreign ownership in Qantas set by the Government. Qantas plans to notify offshore shareholders whose purchases ran above the Government's ceiling. After being notified, those foreign investors in Qantas will have 90 days to sell their shares. (Reuters)

description: Moon and Mind

A CUNY Exodus
description: The City University of New York, in the largest voluntary faculty exodus in 20 years, is losing 472 senior faculty members to early retirement, and officials said they would not be replaced by full-time professors, leaving many classes to part-time teachers. Several longtime professors said the retirement program probably saved jobs by averting layoffs. But they lamented the latest blow to a system already reeling.

title: Can Parochial Schools Teach Public Schools?; El Salvador's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Malaria's Genetic Game Of Cloak and Dagger
description: THE most frightening things in life are not the unknown but the familiar demons that refuse to leave. Among the greatest forces shaping the course of human history, sometimes scooping entire populations off the map, is infectious disease; after a brief, charming fantasy that the age of infectious diseases was behind us, the entire medieval bestiary of scourges has returned with teeth bared and claws extended: tuberculosis, cholera, typhus, virulent pneumonia and that festering tropical fever with the singsong Latinate name, malaria.

title: Young Bull Rider Goes Up Against a Ton of Force
description: Jake Baker is 16 years old. He stands 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighs 124 pounds. Eighty times a year, he rides bulls, the most violent and dangerous event in rodeo and one of the most deadly sports. He has done so since he was 12.

title: Bonds Prices Climb on Hopes The Fed Will Cut Rates Again
description: Bond prices rose in thin trading yesterday, reflecting optimism among a few buyers ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve.

title: Jacksonville Journal; Panting for Football, and Standing Tall
description: Like a late bloomer in a class of overachievers, this city near the Georgia border has long been overshadowed in the Southeast by the likes of Miami, Orlando and Atlanta. And, like guests on the "Oprah Winfrey Show," its residents have no qualms admitting an inferiority complex.

title: Matsushita Plan For Thin TV's
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that it had begun making flat screens to be used as wall-hanging televisions.

title: Driving Home a Point Against a Popular Mayor
description: THE protesters showed up at Mayor Bret Schundler's house yesterday morning at 8:30 sharp, just as his driver pulled up to take him to City Hall. After 30 days, both sides have established what to do.

title: John Gilmore, 63, Saxophonist In the Avant-Garde of Jazz
description: John Gilmore, a tenor saxophonist who helped define the sound of the avant-garde during four decades with the Sun Ra Arkestra, died on Sunday at Germantown Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 63 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If there was any question that the Hamptons increasingly resembles Hollywood, a Saturday softball game, in which a group of artists and performers played against writers, may have clinched the notion.

title: Mayor's Plan on Fire-Alarm Boxes
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved the Giuliani administration's plan to turn off 25 percent of the fire alarm boxes in New York, fewer than the 40 percent the Fire Commissioner proposed at first.

description: SABBATH'S THEATER By Philip Roth 451 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $24.95.

Giants' Williams Finally Returns
description: Regarding the importance one player can have to a baseball team, just ask Dusty Baker about Matt Williams.

title: GENESIS HEALTH VENTURES TO BUY NURSING-HOME OPERATOR
description: Genesis Health Ventures Inc., an operator of nursing homes, said yesterday that it was acquiring McKerley Health Care Centers for about $82.5 million, including assumed debt. McKerley Health, a private company based in Concord, N.H., operates 15 centers that provide care for the elderly in New Hampshire and Vermont. McKerley Health also provides pharmacy services to patients at its centers and operates a home health care business. Genesis, which is based in Kennett Square, Pa., said the transaction was expected to close in the fourth quarter.

title: Mantle Must Share Vaunted Hero Status
description: For the large cosmopolitan city it is, New York is more provincial than Cincinnati or Kansas City. If it doesn't happen here, it doesn't happen anywhere.

title: U.S. Vows to Carry On Work Of 3 Envoys Killed in Bosnia
description: Invoking the myth of Sisyphus, top United States officials paid tribute today to three colleagues who died struggling to bring peace to Bosnia.

title: Signalman Is Hunted as Error Is Blamed for Indian Train Wreck
description: The authorities in India were searching today for the signalman who fled his post after allowing a train onto a track where another train was stopped, leading to a collision early Sunday that killed more than 340 people and injured more than 400.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ABC Apologizes for Saying Nicotine Was Manipulated ABC News apologized to Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds for asserting, on "Day One," that tobacco companies manipulated nicotine levels in cigarettes to addict smokers. "That was a mistake," ABC said, settling a $10 billion libel suit that was to have gone to trial in October.

title: 21 1/2 Years for Drug Smuggler
description: A man from Edison was sentenced yesterday to 21 1/2 years in prison for importing 77 pounds of heroin from Singapore, the largest heroin seizure ever in New Jersey, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Julius Monk, Cabaret Impresario, Dies at 82
description: Julius Monk, the debonair impresario of satiric revues and the diviner of generations of talented performers, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Review/Fashion; The New Shapes of the Shift
description: For years, designers and stores kept trying to bring back the dress. It finally happened in the last year when trimmings and sleeves were discarded and the simple shift of the 1960's was reborn. It was a style that women of any age could wear. Even young women decided the shift (and its more fitted sister, the sheath) could be a hip alternative to pants.

title: 472 Are Leaving Faculty At CUNY to Retire Early
description: The City University of New York, in the largest voluntary faculty exodus in 20 years, is losing 472 senior faculty members to early retirement, and officials said they would not be replaced by full-time professors, leaving many classes to less-experienced, part-time teachers.

title: Avignon Journal; In France's Fabled South, a Plague of Panhandlers
description: George Ducroix had made a modest year-round living holding up his begging cup near the Palace of the Popes. But he was feeling haunted by the "invaders," as he calls them.

title: Russian Assault Recaptures Police Station in Chechnya
description: Using tanks, helicopters and mortar fire, Russian special forces today stormed a Chechen police station that had been seized by about 250 separatist rebels on Sunday.

title: 3 Teams of Adventurers Hope to Circle the Globe in Balloons
description: SOMETIME after Nov. 1, as many as three huge balloons may be in the air at the same time, each of their crews hoping to be the first in the two-century history of ballooning to circumnavigate the world nonstop.

title: Sports of The Times; A Critique Of a Former Champion
description: EVANDER HOLYFIELD sat in his midtown hotel room yesterday morning feeling the effects of a whirlwind interview schedule. Late Sunday evening he had taped a segment of "Good Morning, America." Yesterday he was up and out at 6:30 A.M. to do "Good Morning, New York." Last night, the former heavyweight champion was scheduled to be the guest of honor at a celebrity roast sponsored by the Congress of Racial Equality and its chairman, Roy Innis.

title: Everett's 2 Homers Help Mets Top Giants
description: Bill Pulsipher has advice for those who may doubt that the Mets' recent resurgence is for real.

title: A STAKE IN STILLWATER MINING TO BE SOLD TO INVESTORS
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the 5.4 million shares it owns in the Stillwater Mining Company to a group of institutional investors for $110.4 million. The shares represent a 27 percent interest in Stillwater, a mining company based in Nye, Mont. Manville is selling the stock for $20.50 a share. Manville, a provider of building products that is based in Denver, said the sale would add about $45 million, or 36 cents a share, to its results in the third quarter.

title: Polyphony Of Weather And Music
description: Depending on when, exactly, they arrived in New York, Jaime Laredo and the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen may have been less grateful for the blustery breeze that blew through Damrosch Park on Friday evening than the audience was. It played havoc with the amplification system, producing crackles and rumbles that obviously distracted the players, who were hard put anyway to keep their music in place. As is so often the case at outdoor concerts, such circumstances made it difficult to judge the performances in any detail.

title: In China, Rapid Social Changes Bring a Surge in the Divorce Rate
description: For centuries, ordinary Chinese have greeted each other on the street with a question that reflected the nation's primary concern: "Chi le ma?" or "Have you eaten?"

title: International Briefs; CS Holding's Profit Declines by 3%
description: CS Holding, a Swiss financial services company, said yesterday that its first-half profit had fallen 3 percent, a drop that was less than had been expected, as its CS First Boston unit posted a turnaround and Swiss Volksbank shed bad debt. "The results don't appear as bad as some expected," said Abi Leach, a banking industry analyst at Merrill Lynch.
