description: To The Home Section:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The artist AL HIRSCHFELD is no Deadhead. "I'm a swing enthusiast," said Mr. Hirschfeld, who is 92. But two weeks ago, when MARGO FEIDEN, his dealer of 25 years, suggested that he draw a portrait of the Grateful Dead's Jerry Garcia, who died on Aug. 9, Mr. Hirschfeld produced an image (shown at right) working from photographs of the musician. Mr. Hirschfeld said of the drawing: "It drew itself. It went rather fast, because his character is so obvious, it's so likable."

title: Disabled Man Hears Intruder Kill Wife
description: A 70-year-old woman was killed during a break-in at her Brooklyn home yesterday morning as her bedridden 88-year-old husband listened to her cries from their second-floor bedroom, the police said.

title: A Big Bank Is Not an End in Itself
description: Alchemy might make a comeback in light of the investor Michael Price's ability to turn Chase Manhattan Bank, once America's most prominent bank but now in serious disrepair, into the darling of Wall Street. But who are the ultimate beneficiaries of this magic?

title: Sting on Bogus Cabs in Queens Nets a Yellow One That Isn't
description: It looked like a cab, yellow and cheery. It smelled like a cab, musty and dreary.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK WARNS OF POSSIBLE TOUGH MEASURES
description: Shares of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation dropped 9 percent yesterday after the utility, which is based in Syracuse, warned that it might be forced to cut its dividend or take other steps in a difficult business climate. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Niagara Mohawk complained of growing competition, a sluggish economy, regulatory obstacles and other adverse influences on its business. Niagara Mohawk said it might have to restructure contracts or take "even more severe actions" to "keep the company financially viable." Niagara Mohawk's shares fell $1.25, to $12.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Growth Revised Upward, but It Was Still Weak
description: The economy grew at a somewhat faster clip in the second quarter than originally estimated, the Government said yesterday, but the rate of expansion was still the weakest in nearly four years.

title: Shaky 9th-Grade Test Results As Math and Science Toughen
description: Even though thousands more New York City ninth graders took and passed tougher college-level mathematics and science courses this spring, only a relative few passed the statewide standardized tests for those subjects.

title: Picketers' Efforts Scaled Back
description: After the 38th day of picketing at the home of Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, protesters were ordered by a Superior Court judge yesterday to scale back their effort. The Mayor has sued to try to stop the picketing by a group of residents who are angry because the city's highest-ranking black officer was reassigned from a policy-making role to a supervisory post. Judge Richard T. Nieto ordered the group to demonstrate only from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. two days a week, with no more than four people at a time. The group's leader, Councilwoman Melissa Holloway, said she would simply move the demonstration to City Hall on the other days.

title: Minneapolis Paper Honors Past and Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column in the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about an auction of dictionaries signed by celebrities to benefit the Noah Webster House in West Hartford misstated the date. It will be on Sept. 29, not tomorrow.

title: Court Orders Students in Bias Case to Take Sensitivity Course
description: The case against three Manhattan high school students charged with harassing a teacher with an anti-Semitic note was dismissed yesterday by a criminal court judge on one condition: that they attend an anti-bias course and perform community service for Jewish organizations.

title: No Headline
description: "These were the only detonations of the whole war that made us happy. NATO has given us the hope we had lost." MAIDA DAJDZIC, a 35-year-old Sarajevo woman. [ A1:4. ]

title: Woman and Daughter Stabbed to Death
description: A 17-year-old girl and her mother were stabbed to death Tuesday night by two men who broke into their home and spent hours ransacking it, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: How Blacklisting Hurt Hollywood Children
description: To most American children in the late 1940's, J. Edgar Hoover was a hero, a stern but steadfast bulwark against crime and chaos. To young Tony Kahn, however, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was a bogeyman: a relentless enemy who attacked his family by day and unleashed faceless monsters, which pursued him through his dreams, by night.

title: When Texans Say 'One Ranger, One Riot'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fischer Black, 57, Wall Street Theorist, Dies
description: Fischer Black, an economist whose groundbreaking work in financial theory helped revolutionize modern Wall Street, died yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after a yearlong battle with cancer, his family said.

title: Montreal Lays On A Feast of Cinema, Bigger Than Ever
description: Can a festival be big and small at the same time? Yes, if it's the Montreal World Film Festival. The festival, now in its 19th year, is bigger than ever. By the time the last reel of film has unspooled on Monday night, about 300,000 viewers will have seen 400 films from 63 countries in 12 days. Only in Montreal can die-hard film buffs expect to see not one but three films from Mongolia. As a commercial force, however, the festival is probably less important now than at any time in its history.

title: No Audibles by Marino Concerning Stock Deal
description: Dan Marino wants to talk about football, only football. In a conference call today, Marino would not discuss the National Football League's investigation into a stock windfall from the quarterback's $390,000 purchase in May of part of a company owned by the Dolphins' owner, Wayne Huizenga. The company stock has since quintupled in value and Marino's stake is now worth almost $2 million.

title: CS First Boston Newcomer To Build Mortgage Products
description: Seeking to bolster its mortgage- and asset-backed securities business, cobiCS First Boston has hired Andrew D. Stone, the former head of the mortgage products business of Daiwa Securities America Inc.

title: Gasoline Prices Surge on Report Of Sinking Inventories in U.S.
description: Gasoline prices rose sharply yesterday after a report showed that gasoline inventories in the United States fell last week to their lowest level in more than two decades.

title: Rift on Fuhrman Tapes
description: The racial epithets of Mark Fuhrman that aired at the O. J. Simpson trial have exposed deep racial divisions within Los Angeles and its police department. Some residents and police officers said the comments could aggravate racial and ethnic tensions in the city.

title: PURCHASE OF 60 HOME SAVINGS BRANCHES GETS APPROVAL
description: The New York State Banking Department has approved Greenpoint Savings Bank's $660 million purchase of 60 Home Savings branches, H. F. Ahmanson and Company, the parent of Home Savings, said yesterday. The deal was announced on May 15. In July, Inner City Press/Community on the Move, a New York City community group, had asked the banking department and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to review the deal, questioning Greenpoint's compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act. Greenpoint is a unit of the Greenpoint Financial Corporation, based in Flushing, Queens. Ahmanson is based in Irwindale, Calif.

title: ABC Adds 2 TV Stations
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of two VHF television stations -- WJRT-TV in Flint, Mich., and WTVG-TV in Toledo, Ohio -- for $155 million. Capital Cities said the acquisitions raised to 10 the number of television stations it owns and operates. WJRT-TV in Flint is already an ABC affiliate; WTVG-TV in Toledo will switch to ABC from its affiliation with NBC.

title: Part of the Problem
description: To The Home Section:

title: Ex-Detective's Tapes Fan Racial Tensions in Los Angeles
description: Mark Fuhrman's racist comments, heard on tape and read from transcripts yesterday at O. J. Simpson's murder trial, have exposed deep racial divisions within Los Angeles and its police force.

title: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc.(FLE,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Jul 30
description: Revenue is operating revenues.The latest first quarter had 13 weeks of operations, compared with 14 weeks in year-ago period.

title: Perot Tells Senate Committee It's Time to Get Experts' Opinions on Reining In Medicare
description: Ross Perot, who made a fortune selling computer services to the Government, lectured Congress today on how to save Medicare from bankruptcy, saying the program must be re-engineered by experts with fresh ideas for controlling costs.

title: Mid Ocean Ltd.(MOCNF,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Jul 31
description: The latest quarter included investment gain of $ 15,308,000, or 41 cents a share, compared with an investment loss of $ 15,630,000, or 41 cents a share, in year-ago period.Mid Ocean said that excluding investment gains and losses, it had operating income of $ 50.8 million, or $ 1.35 a share, in the fiscal third quarter, compared with $ 36.1 million, or 95 cents a share, in year-ago period.

title: Tufts Divided on Freshman Who Killed Mother
description: As they awaited Gina Grant's arrival at Tufts University today, students voiced criticism and support for the 19-year-old Miss Grant, whose admission to Harvard University was rescinded after it was learned that she had killed her mother.

title: ABORTION METHOD USING TWO DRUGS GAINS IN A STUDY
description: A large new study being published in a leading medical journal concludes that abortions can be safely and effectively performed in early pregnancy by administering two prescription drugs that are already widely available.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Where's the Rain?

title: For a Change, Crash of Shells Heartens Sarajevo Residents
description: The people of Sarajevo cheered the shells that rocked them from their slumber overnight and lit the night sky with orange traces. These were not the Bosnian Serbs' guns, which regularly pounded their city, killing their relatives, neighbors and friends over the past 40 months. The impossible had happened -- NATO was bombing the Bosnian Serbs.

title: Weather Threatens Launching of Shuttle
description: Low, dark clouds and rain, the lingering effects of Tropical Storm Jerry, threatened to delay the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour, scheduled for 11:04 A.M. on Thursday.

title: Wide Net Cast in U.S. Inquiry on Gathering
description: In an unusual mass questioning, Federal investigators are surveying more than 50,000 law-enforcement officers to find out who attended a country picnic in the East Tennessee mountains that may have included racist and anti-Semitic activities.

title: CHANGES FORCED IN PLAN FOR KEMPER BROKERAGE
description: The Kemper Corporation of Long Grove, Ill., said yesterday that regulators had forced it to scrap a proposal to spin off common stock in its brokerage unit to shareholders. Under a revised plan Kemper is submitting to the Securities and Exchange Commission, shareholders would receive preferred stock, instead of common, in Kemper's Everen Capital Corporation unit. The new transaction values Everen at about $101 million, about 60 percent of the value at which Kemper carried the brokerage firm on its books at the end of 1994. The lower valuation is forcing the company to take an $18 million charge against its third-quarter earnings. Kemper said the transaction would satisfy conditions of its agreement to be bought by a group led by the Zurich Insurance Company of Switzerland.

title: G&K Services Inc.(GKSRA,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Jul 1
Man in Jordan Prison for Murder Of Wife in New Jersey Is Indicted
description: A man who is serving time in a Jordanian prison for strangling his wife in New Jersey was indicted today by a Morris County grand jury on charges of first-degree murder and kidnapping.

title: N.B.A. Vote Raises Puzzling Questions
description: National Basketball Association players went to the polls yesterday, but many didn't like it and many were confused.

title: Butcher in Bronx Is Killed, And Police Suspect Mob Hit
description: A 71-year-old Bronx butcher was shot to death and his brother was critically injured late Tuesday during a drive-by shooting that the police said appeared to be a mob hit.

title: Reeves Gives Giants a Wake-Up Call for Cowboys
description: Kent Graham went to work this morning thinking it would be like any other day. When he arrived at Giants Stadium, Coach Dan Reeves wanted to speak to him. It was the beginning of a day that would rock the Giants' locker room; a day when Dave Brown should begin looking over his shoulder.

title: After City's Public Hospitals Close Their Doors; Emergency-Room Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD COMBINES COMPUTER-RELATED UNITS
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has combined its computer-related businesses and promoted Richard Belluzzo, 41, to run them. Mr. Belluzzo has headed the division responsible for printers and personal computers, and he will now supervise work stations, larger computer systems, consulting and customer-service operations as well. Sales from all units in the new division totaled $19.6 billion in 1994, 78.5 percent of the company's revenue.

title: Boston Scientific to Gain in Heart Technology Takeover
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Heart Technology Inc., a maker of a device that reopens clogged arteries, in a stock swap valued at $500 million.

title: Lawyers Prepare for New York's Death Penalty
description: Dennis C. Vacco, the New York Attorney General, says his motives were pure when he sent a letter to state prosecutors, saying he was ready to help them press the new death penalty, which takes effect tomorrow. He already has a team -- two trial lawyers and an investigator -- primed to rush in at a moment's notice.

title: 3-Way Haggle Is Now Shaping Deal for Turner
description: Executives of Time Warner Inc., Turner Broadcasting System, and Tele-Communications Inc. shuttled between hotel suites and conference rooms in New York yesterday in a rush to work out a deal in which Time Warner would acquire Turner for roughly $8.5 billion.

title: SEAGRAM COMPANY (VO,N)
description: The Seagram Company reported yesterday that its earnings from continuing operations nearly doubled in the second quarter, although its net income fell 60 percent, reflecting the sale of its stake in E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Chinese Aides Vex a Women's Forum
description: Just after dawn today, a senior staff member of an international women's forum assembling here left her hotel room for stroll around Huairou reservoir, where the mist-shrouded Fragrant Hills loomed to the west and the morning light caught delicate pagodas in silhouette.

title: Currents; New Ways To Tame Small Space
description: "WE architects are being asked to make a lot out of a little today," said Norman Smith of Washington, the author of the new "Small Space Living Design" (Rockport, $34.95). "Houses have to work harder."

title: The Marriage of Art and Money
description: ART AND MONEY By Marc Shell Illustrated. 213 pages. University of Chicago Press. $35.

After Karl Marx, a 1,000-Year-Old Superman
description: Yuldash Yusupov, a local car mechanic, is preparing to sacrifice a sheep near his felt tent in this mountain-ringed capital, then to feast on the animal's blood.

title: Mexican Officials Stand by Theory Drug Gang Killed Cardinal
description: After more than two years of investigation, the questioning of scores of witnesses and the pursuit of hundreds of leads, the Mexican authorities say they have reached a tentative conclusion about the murder of the Roman Catholic Cardinal of Guadalajara.

title: International Briefs; Axa Planning to Buy A French Reinsurer
description: Compagnie de Suez S.A., the huge French financial services company, will sell the reinsurer Abeille Reassurances to Axa S.A. for 2.52 billion francs ($503 million) in cash and convertible bonds, the two companies said yesterday. The acquisition would create the largest reinsurer in France.

description: DROVES of parents and school-age children (in small, medium and large sizes) are now preparing for earlier bedtimes, school bus schedules and -- groan -- homework.

title: Expensive, Exotic Birds Are Targets Of Thieves
description: A trio of thieves has stolen at least five exotic birds valued at more than $1,000 each from pet shops in Nassau County in the last week, the police said today.

title: No Seal of Approval for Video
description: Officials of the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace said yesterday that they did not seek Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's permission before they began selling a videotape of a speech she made at the library last April. "Since the Governor was a public official speaking at a public event on matters of public interest, the library did not seek her permission to release the video," officials said. Democrats are angry that taxpayers footed the $9,500 bill to fly Governor Whitman and security officials to California to make a partisan speech and want her to reimburse the state.

title: AT HOME WITH/Kinky Friedman; Married to the Wind
description: There's nothing Kinky Friedman likes better than talking about himself. He's totally self-absorbed, and he's fully aware of it.

title: With L.I. Fire Nearly in Check, Tanker Planes Are Sent Home
description: The giant tanker planes sent to Long Island on Saturday to fight a mammoth brush fire left for home today as Federal officials said they were close to declaring the blaze under control.

title: One Twin Killed, Other Is Hurt
description: One twin brother was killed and the other critically wounded when a gun battle broke out late Tuesday at a grocery story, the police said. Eric Dixon, 30, of Elizabeth, had been feuding with the twins, Dwight and Dwayne Foster, 20, also of Elizabeth, and shot them both before being wounded in the leg by an unknown gunman, said Lieut. Mark Kurdyla, a police spokesman.

title: NATO PRESSES BOSNIA BOMBING, VOWING TO MAKE SARAJEVO SAFE
description: After 40 months of awkward hesitation, NATO today stepped squarely into the midst of the Bosnian war, pounding Bosnian Serb targets with air strikes across the country and declaring that the bombardment would not stop until Sarajevo was secure.

title: Safer Than Ever
description: To The Home Section:

title: The Fun Begins Near the Lockers
description: The Flushing Meadows tennis complex is usually the target of player complaints, most of them justified, but Luke Jensen had only accolades for the renovated locker room.

title: Seizing the Future, Or Running Scared?
description: Gerald M. Levin has been running uphill ever since he got the job of chairman at Time Warner Inc. in early 1993. He inherited a company with loads of promise but lots of problems. And judging by the stock market's response in recent years, his performance has hardly been dazzling.

title: Sex and Low Humor Beyond Shakespeare's
description: K. G. Wilson apparently decided that if there is confusion about sex and identity in "Twelfth Night," along with some low humor, there might as well be more of both. In the Kings County Shakespeare Company production playing at the band shell in Prospect Park in Brooklyn through Sunday, this energetic director changes several male roles into female ones and often turns the antics of Sir Toby Belch and his friends into slapstick. (The one person who always rises above that level is Lynn Marie Macy as Maria the maid: bawdy, sexy, smart, as tempting as spiced honey.)

title: No Hinges. No Knobs. No Jeans, Either.
description: WHERE the ads are loaded with innuendo, the store is all proportion and purity. Architecturally speaking, of course.

title: Sacrifices From New York's Teachers
description: Not since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's have New York City schools been as financially strapped as they are now. The Board of Education's projected spending has already been cut $500 million this year and the system is struggling to find roughly $230 million in additional cuts before school starts in a week.

title: INSIDE
description: Finding on Mystery Leg

title: Dole Disappoints in Log Cabin Rebuff
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; A Boutique Of Exclusives
description: IF it's not an antique, it's exclusive to Slatkin," is how Harry Slatkin describes the items for sale at the new 800-square-foot Slatkin & Company boutique at Bergdorf Goodman, which opens Sept. 8. "We design everything ourselves. There's nothing here you'll find anywhere else."

title: Bartlett Jere Whiting, 90, an Authority on Chaucer and Proverbs
description: Bartlett Jere Whiting, a professor emeritus of English at Harvard University who was renowned for his compilations of proverbs and for his classes on Chaucer, died last Thursday at Waldo County Hospital in Belfast, Me. He was 90 and lived in Northport, Me., in the house where he was born.

title: Four-Posters for Fido
description: IN the doggy days of summer, where might a dog lay its weary head?

title: Goal of Bombers: The Bargaining Table
description: When he learned of the intensive NATO air strikes on Bosnian Serb positions around Sarajevo, the President of Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government, Alija Izetbegovic, told reporters, "The world has finally done what it should have done a long, long time ago."

title: In 'trolling for sponsors,' organizers of the 1996 Games are playing against the clock -- and trailing.
description: WITH less than 11 months to go before the torch is lit, Atlanta's Olympic organizers are entering the final miles of their marathon effort to raise all of their planned revenue -- $1.59 billion -- entirely from nongovernmental sources. And by all accounts, it remains an uphill struggle.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMMUNITY BANKSHARES INC., Concord, N.H., a savings and loan holding company, plans to acquire Centerpoint Bank, Bedford, N.H., a state-chartered commercial bank, for $10.5 million, or $17.70 a share, in a stock-swap transaction. HOME SHOPPING NETWORK INC., Clearwater, Fla., said it was seeking a buyer for a subsidiary, Ortho-Vent Inc. of Salem, Va., which markets Stuart McGuire men's shoes via mail orders.

title: Murder Charges Against Kevorkian in 1991 Case Are Dismissed
description: Murder charges against Dr. Jack Kevorkian were dismissed today by a Michigan judge, who then indicated that if asked, he would order the doctor to be tried instead on charges of assisted suicide in a 1991 case involving the deaths of two women.

title: Some Protest Vulgarities; Networks Back Their Use
description: Some cable-television viewers found Mark Fuhrman's words so offensive that they complained after hearing his racial slurs and barnyard language on Tuesday. But cable executives said yesterday that they had no second thoughts on their handling of the tape recordings in the O. J. Simpson murder trial.

title: City's Homicide Rate Climbs
description: The murder rate in the state's poorest city is accelerating. A paroled drug dealer was fatally shot on Monday, becoming the 43d person to be killed in Camden this year, the A.P. reported yesterday. Last year at this time, nine fewer homicides had been recorded.

title: Currents; How to Succeed . . .
description: NOW you can enter middle management without ever leaving home. A new game, "The Tom Peters Business School in a Box," was designed and written by Eric Goldberg, a simulation-game designer, with Tom Peters, a co-author of the best-selling book "In Search of Excellence."

title: Sports of The Times; Learning The Fax Of Strife
description: OUTSIDE Room 3614 at 26 Federal Plaza yesterday in lower Manhattan, the polls were open and Anthony Mason was getting some last-minute counsel from his agent, Don Cronson.

title: SUNRIVER SYSTEMS TO BUY COMPUTER TEXT TERMINALS UNIT
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its text terminals business to Sunriver Data Systems Inc., based in Austin, Tex., a maker of computer terminals and software. Terms were not disclosed. Text terminals are combined screens and keyboards whose information is processed through a detached computer. As part of the deal, Sunriver will supply text terminals for Digital to sell. Digital, the computer company based in Maynard, Mass., said it would continue to service the text terminals customers are using now. Sunriver Data is a unit of All-Quotes Inc., also based in Austin.

title: L.I. Wildfire: Nature's Tool
description: Late last Thursday night, Susie Rasmussen was hosing down her porch and trees in Westhampton to keep falling cinders the size of quarters from burning her house on Montauk Highway near the blazing pine barrens.

title: Execution of Retarded Man Is Fought
description: The best reason that Barry Lee Fairchild should not be executed on Thursday occurred at his clemency hearing two weeks ago, Mr. Fairchild's lawyer said today.

title: Stocks Post Modest Increases, but Dow Still Declines by 3.87
description: Stocks posted modest gains yesterday after Time Warner Inc. offered to buy Turner Broadcasting System for $8.5 billion, touching off a rally in media shares.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Ground Zero To Promote Running
description: The Athletic Footwear Association in North Palm Beach, Fla., has selected Ground Zero in Venice, Calif., as its first agency to handle advertising and marketing communications to promote running in the United States. The billings were estimated at $3 million. Ground Zero was awarded the account on Tuesday after a review that was narrowed to that agency and two others, Selz Seabolt in Chicago and Target Marketing in New York.

title: Officials Say Hospitals Chief Was Accused Of Harassment
description: When Dr. Bruce Siegel resigned abruptly as head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation on Tuesday, he was under investigation after allegations of sexual harassment, several city and hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Trumpeter Shows Off Surprises
description: The Panasonic Village Jazz Festival held its major event on its last day: a free concert by the Roy Hargrove Big Band in Washington Square Park on Monday afternoon. Mr. Hargrove, an outstanding young trumpeter, usually leads small groups, and his big band was a cautious advance into new territory.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an initial public offering planned by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. misstated when the Equitable Companies acquired the brokerage firm in some editions. It was 1985, not 1974.

title: Testimony Ends in Terror-Bombing Trial
description: After seven months and more than 200 witnesses, testimony ended last night in the bombing conspiracy trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and nine other men.

title: Heidemij NV(HEIDF,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jun 30
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 500,000, or 3 cents a share, from sale of nonconsolidated companies.Revenue is gross revenues. The net revenues totaled $ 111.4 million in the latest quarter and $ 92 million in year-ago period.The results are in United States dollars and based on U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Regarding the Dutch guilder, the dollar exchange rate for latest second quarter: $ 1.00 equaled 1.55; year-ago rate was $ 1.00 equaled 1.84.

title: MAJORITY SHAREHOLDERS PLAN TO TAKE SYMS PRIVATE
description: The Syms Corporation said yesterday that its majority shareholders planned to take the company private and to retire its stock for about $8.75 a share. The majority shareholders include the chief executive, Sy Syms; the president, Marcy Syms, and the secretary, Stephen Merns. Sy Syms holds about 54 percent of the shares, said Harry C. Kleinman, the company's vice president and chief financial officer. Mr. Kleinman declined to estimate the value of the deal. The shares of Syms, a clothing retailer based in Secaucus, N. J., closed at $8.125 a share, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Prudential Pact: $110 Million To Settle Suit
description: Nearly two years after Prudential Securities agreed to repay every customer it cheated in the biggest investment fraud in history, the firm has been forced to open its wallet again.

title: Parents Sue Romania Over Child's H.I.V. Infection
description: Challenging a Government with one of the worst records for AIDS prevention in Europe, a couple is suing the Romanian Health Ministry for causing the H.I.V. infection of their daughter.

title: S.& L.'s Win Court Victory Against U.S.
description: In a ruling that could mean billions of dollars for the savings and loan industry, a Federal appeals court said today that the Government was liable for damages for abruptly changing the rules by which savings and loan associations were allowed to calculate their assets when they took over weaker institutions.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common * Enterprise Systems Inc., Wheeling, Ill., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 2.35 million shares in an initial public offering. Robertson, Stephens will be the lead underwriter.

title: Japanese Stocks Rise
description: Stocks rose here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 133.36 points, or 0.74 percent, to 18,117.22. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 151.30 points, dragged down by shares of banking companies after regulators shut down the Kizu Credit Union.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp.(LANC,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Jun 30
description: The year-ago share and per-share figures adjusted for 4-for-3 stock split in July 1994.

title: Koor Industries reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jun 30
description: The results are in United States dollars.

title: Treasury Prices Advance On Fed Official's Comment
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday, helped by a stronger dollar and by comments from a top Federal Reserve official pointing to lower interest rates.

title: When Holtz Needs Help, He Looks Back to Hayes
description: The name Lou Holtz had not yet been listed among college football's coaching giants, because he had not yet become Lou Holtz. He was 32 years old in the spring of 1969, a wise-cracking, pipe-smoking assistant at Ohio State, his fifth stop in the business.

title: Arrest Order for Lassiter
description: An arrest order was issued in Raleigh, N.C., yesterday for ROY LASSITER, a member of the United States national soccer team, after he failed to appear for a hearing on 3-year-old charges of breaking-and-entering and forgery.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: LAWYERS PREPARE FOR THE DEATH PENALTY Dennis C. Vacco, the New York Attorney General, says his motives were pure when he sent prosecutors a letter saying he was ready to help them press the new death penalty. But while he is on standby for prosecutors, they may not be standing by for him. [ Page A1. ] Governor Pataki announced that a prison near the Canadian border would house the state's death row, and that a Dutchess County prison would be the site of the executions. [ B4. ] NEW YORK CITY BUTCHER KILLED IN POSSIBLE MOB HIT A 71-year-old Bronx butcher was shot to death and his brother was critically injured during a drive-by shooting that the police said appeared to be a mob hit. [ B3. ] POLICE CRACK DOWN ON ILLEGAL CABS Police officers and taxi inspectors cracking down on illegal cars for hire in Queensfound an elegant forgery, officials said. [ B3. ] HARLEM DEVELOPMENT AGENCY IS CLOSED The Pataki administration shut down the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a semi-independent agency that used state and private financing to spur economic activity. [ B3. ] DISPUTE ON CITY BUS ENDS IN SHOOTOUT A dispute that began aboard a city bus in the Bronx ended in a blazing shootout when two fleeing passengers and pursuing police officers exchanged about a dozen shots. [ B3. ] JUDGE SENDS STUDENTS TO ANTI-BIAS CLASS The case against three students charged with harassing a teacher with an anti-Semitic note was dismissed on condition that they attend an anti-bias course and perform community service for Jewish organizations. [ B5. ] THREAT OF TEACHER LAYOFFS EASES The prospect of teacher layoffs this fall has diminished considerably, officials said. [ B8. ] REGION WIFE CHARGED IN THEFT OF ART In 1984, O. Winston Link, a well-known photographer, married Conchita Mendoza at a symbolic spot in Green Cove, Va., that was the setting for several of his pictures. Now the lives of the couple, since divorced, have arrived at a less scenic but equally dramatic stop: a courthouse in Westchester County. [ B6. ] KEAN DECIDES NOT TO RUN FOR SENATE Saying Washington had become "mean-spirited," former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey announced that he would not run for the Senate seat that Bill Bradley is giving up. [ B6. ] PANEL BACKS MAJOR FIX-UP FOR ERIE CANAL A New York State commission approved a $146 million plan to remake the Erie Canal into a 524-mile-long tourist attraction. [ B7. ] EXOTIC BIRDS STOLEN FROM L.I. PET SHOPS Thieves have stolen at least five exotic birds valued at more than $1,000 each from pet shops in Nassau County, the police said. [ B9. ] INDICTMENT AWAITS MAN HELD IN JORDAN A man who is serving time in a Jordanian prison for strangling his wife in New Jersey was indicted by a Morris County grand jury on charges of murder and kidnapping. [ B9. ] MOTHER AND DAUGHTER STABBED TO DEATH A girl and her mother were stabbed to death by men who broke into their Brentwood, L.I., home, the police said. [ B10. ] Governor Pataki said that New York had been traditionally shortchanged in the web of operations administered by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. [ B9. ]

title: Dairy Mart reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 29
description: b-Net loss, which included nonrecurring pretax charge of $ 1.8 million for expenses associated with the removal of a former executive.(Loss)

title: Noted Photographer's Wife Charged in Theft of His Art
description: In 1984, O. Winston Link, a well-known photographer of steam engines and railroad towns, married Conchita Mendoza at a symbolic spot, a general store in Green Cove, Va., that was the setting for several of his pictures.

title: Montreal Trustco reports earnings for 2d qtr to Jul 31
description: b-Net loss, which included a $ 230,000 provision for securities losses, $ 105,444,000 in goodwill written off, $ 140,164,000 in other provisions and write-offs, and $ 120,700 in restructuring costs. The period also included a tax credit of $ 55,550,000.The year-ago quarter represented the three months ended June 30. The company recently changed its fiscal year-end to Oct. 31 from Dec. 31.Montreal Trustco is owned by Bank of Nova Scotia.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: QUARTERLY DIVIDEND IS RAISED BY 21%, TO $1 A SHARE
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it had raised the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 21 percent, to $1 from 82.5 cents. The food company, brewer and cigarette maker, which is based in New York, said the dividend would be paid on Oct. 10 to shareholders who had purchased stock before Sept. 15.

title: North Korea's New Target: The Armistice
description: On the most heavily fortified border in the world, the Communist authorities of North Korea appear to be trying to destroy the armistice that has kept the peace since the end of the Korean War.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Audience Research To Buy ASI Unit
description: Audience Research and Development in Dallas, a research and consulting company, has agreed to acquire ASI Entertainment in Glendale, Calif., a market research organization owned by ASI Market Research that specializes in entertainment research. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Calendar: Art, Talks And Farmers' Designs
description: Mississippi Inspiration Liberty Street Gallery, World Financial Center (225 Liberty Street off West Street); (212) 945-0505.

title: Panel Backs Major Fix-Up Of Erie Canal For Tourists
description: Over the objections of Gov. George E. Pataki, a state commission today approved a $146 million plan to remake the Erie Canal into a 524-mile-long tourist attraction replete with outdoor cafes, bike paths and pier-side retail shops.

title: Currents; Playing With the Magic Of Light
description: THE main waiting room at Grand Central Terminal is "on a Roman scale," said Hsin-Ming Fung of Hodgetts & Fung, Los Angeles architects who designed the installation "The Magic of Play," a monthlong photography show opening there on Tuesday. "You can never win over this space, so we played with its scale," she said.

title: In the Northernmost State, Politics Takes a Pugilistic Turn
description: Politics in the Last Frontier State has long been a bare-knuckle trade where opinions are seldom sheathed in the kind of politeness found elsewhere. But even by local standards, the recent physical attack on a visiting Democratic lawyer from Capitol Hill has left many people stunned.
